newsitem.title: GERMANY: Kohl sues Penthouse over naked cartoon of wife.
newsitem.headline: Kohl sues Penthouse over naked cartoon of wife.

text.p: Chancellor Helmut Kohl is suing the German edition of the men's magazine Penthouse for damages for printing a cartoon of his wife wearing nothing but gloves and a pearl necklace, the German government said on Tuesday.

The drawing depicts Hannelore Kohl as the figurine on the radiator grille of a government limousine with a "D", Germany's international automobile symbol, hanging from her necklace and an obviously approving chancellor at the wheel behind her.
"We just thought there hadn't been enough recognition for Mrs Kohl as the show girl of the nation," said Penthouse editor Peter Herzfeld.
"It was just meant as a humorous comment on her role as the chancellor's accompaniment for the last 14 years. We couldn't know Mrs Kohl would find it offensive."
The portly, folksy chancellor has himself been the butt of thousands of irreverent cartoons. But the couple felt the caricature of his wife was going too far.
In response to an inquiry, a government spokesman confirmed the Kohls had filed a civil suit for "infringement of personal rights", and had also filed a criminal suit for defamation.
Press reports said the Kohls were seeking damages of 100,000 marks ($58,000).

Curious readers wanting to see the cartoon face problems. The Kohls secured a court injunction in January which forced Penthouse to stop distributing that month's edition and even prevents the editor sending out copies by fax.
